get through.translation[0].definitions[0: to do an amount of work
We got through half the application forms this morning.
We’ve got a lot of work to get through.
get through.translation[0].definitions[1: to use a lot of something
You wouldn’t believe the amount of food children can get through in a week!
get through.translation[0].definitions[2: to spend a lot of money
He can get through £100 in one evening.
get through.translation[0].definitions[3: to come successfully to the end of an unpleasant experience or period of time, or to help someone do this
I don’t know how we’re going to get through the winter.
It was their love that got me through those first difficult months.
get through.translation[0].definitions[4: to be successful in a test or competition, or to make sure that someone or something is successful
I finally managed to get through my driving test.
I knew it was going to be difficult to get the car through its MOT test.
Liverpool have got through to the final of the FA Cup.
get through.translation[0].definitions[5: to reach a place or person that is difficult to reach
Aid agencies have been unable to get through to the thousands of refugees stranded on the border.
get through.translation[0].definitions[6: to succeed in speaking to someone on the telephone
I tried phoning her office, but I couldn’t get through.
At last I managed to get through to one of the managers.
get through.translation[0].definitions[7: if a new law gets through parliament, or if someone gets it through, it is officially approved
Anti-hunting legislation will never get through the House of Lords.
Once again we failed to get the Bill through Parliament.
get through.translation[1].definitions[0: to succeed in making someone understand something, especially when this is difficult
Including a joke gives your message impact and more chance of getting through.
The party seems unable to get through to young voters.
get through.translation[1].definitions[1: to succeed in having a plan, law etc approved by an official group
His deficit reduction plan eventually got through Congress.
get through.translation[1].definitions[2: to succeed in reaching someone by telephone
The brokers received so many phone calls that many investors couldn’t get through.
It could take a client up to half an hour to get through to his dealer.
get through.translation[1].definitions[3: to deal with a large number of things in a particular order
We never seem to get through all the items on the agenda.
get through.translation[1].definitions[4: to manage to come to the end of a difficult situation or experience
The company got through a major restructuring without making any redundancies.
get through.translation[1].definitions[5: to use a lot of something or spend a lot of money
He got through at least $500 every weekend.
get through.translation[1].definitions[6: if the price of something gets through a particular level on a financial market, it rises above that level
The failure of the dollar to get through 79.15 yen prompted the sudden sell-off.
